[SYNTAX]: Excessively long, convoluted sentence structures (e.g., "As the glovemaker looked out...")
[LEXICON]: Archaic vocabulary ("gadding," "fopperies") may impede modern readability

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt shift from descriptive prose to dense historical exposition (e.g., Pompadour details)
[TRANSITION]: Lack of clear connection between Grasse setting and biographical/historical events
[CLARITY]: Overly elaborate descriptions delay narrative progression (e.g., "the glory of it bathed the lad's eyes...")

[GRAMMAR]: Incorrect verb form ("shoulded" instead of "should") - [SPELLING/Grammar] Missing verb ("had been" instead of "am")

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt inclusion of historical event (Damiens' attack) without clear narrative link
[TRANSITION]: Slightly disconnected introduction of Natoire's shift in opinion

[GRAMMAR]: Incorrect verb tense in "He become a national hero" (should be "became").

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt transition from Fragonard’s Italy stay to unrelated French political intrigue without contextual bridge.

[GRAMMAR]: Missing past tense in "Fragonard lose patience" (should be "lost"). - [SPELLING/TYPO] "bit tongue" (likely "biting").

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt shift from Fragonard’s patrons to historical/political context (e.g., Jesuit/Choiseul narrative).
[TRANSITION]: Lack of clear connective tissue between artistic and historical segments.

[GRAMMAR]: Incorrect pronoun usage ("his was" instead of "he was").
[LEXICON]: Archaic phrasing (e.g., "fell a-painting," "rough accent of Provence").

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt mention of Boucher’s decline without contextual connection.

[GRAMMAR]: Subject-verb agreement error ("wit and ruthless fatuity am") - [SPELLING/Grammar] Typo in "to gave him due credit" (should be "give")
[LEXICON]: Archaic phrasing may impede modern readability

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from political downfall to Fragonard’s Italy journey without clear connection
[STRUCTURE]: Non-sequential blending of historical events and biographical details

[GRAMMAR]: Incorrect verb tense ("It come" instead of "came") - [SPELLING/Grammar] "reeled" instead of "reel" in "was to reeled"
[SYNTAX]: "as his master Boucher have been granted" (subject-verb agreement error)

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt transition from Fragonard’s personal life to detailed historical events
[CLARITY]: Assumed background knowledge of Revolution figures/events without introduction
[TRANSITION]: Lack of explicit connectors between paragraphs (e.g., personal vs. historical narrative)

[GRAMMAR]: Incorrect verb tense ("see" instead of "saw") and typos ("coulded").

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt transitions between historical events and Fragonard’s personal narrative (e.g., shift from Terror to Napoleon’s rise).
[TRANSITION]: Lack of clear links between paragraphs (e.g., "Meanwhile" feels disconnected).

[LEXICON]: Overly complex vocabulary (e.g., "prodigal hand," "mock-heroic") may slow readability.
[SYNTAX]: Occasionally dense, winding sentence structures (e.g., descriptive passages about Fragonard’s appearance).

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from biographical events to artistic legacy analysis (e.g., "Thus pass away..." to "Painting with prodigal hand...").
[STRUCTURE]: Segments on family outcomes and broader art commentary feel loosely connected to the core narrative.
